ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book A Friend Like You and learned about how Squirrel and the bird became friends.

In this activity, we will look at pictures and talk about what we see. Do you see something that friends do together? What? At the end of the activity, we will have a list that we can call “How to Be a Good Friend.”

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show a picture card and ask children what they think is happening in the picture. Ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Record Give the card to a pair of children and ask them what part of friendship they think the picture is showing. Write it down as they dictate it to you. Keep a running list.
Repeat Continue with the next card.

Talk About Friendship Read aloud the dictated friendship list. Invite children to talk about which things they do with their friends. Encourage them to show the matching picture card as they talk about the things they do with their friends. Make sure all children have a chance to contribute to the conversation.
For children who need additional support, identify the action on each picture card. For example, share, comfort, play ball, blow bubbles, play on the playground, and sing.
After discussing each picture, ask children to share a time when they did something similar with one of their friends.

It’s possible that certain actions we think are important to friendship have variations in different cultures. Be sensitive to cultural differences during this activity. Invite children to share other actions that they think are an important part of friendship. They may want to share words from their home language that describe such actions.
In a large open space, have children work in pairs to act out the different actions they saw on the cards. They may want to adapt the action so it’s closer to something that they would really do.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we revisited the book A Friend Like You and talked about things friends like to do together.
It’s fun to play with our friends. Sometimes you might ask a friend to play with you. Sometimes someone might ask you to play. It’s fun to play with just one friend or with a group of friends.

One way to find new friends is to find people who like the same things that you do. In this activity, we’re going to look at pictures of different activities we do at school. We will find out who in our group likes the same thing. Everyone who likes what is on that card will move to the center of the circle. Then we’ll pick another card. This is a fun activity that will help us learn more about each other and find friends we can play with during the school day.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Gather in a circle and show one of the cards to the children. Ask the question on the back of the card. Ask all children who like what’s on the card to move to the center of the circle, creating an inner circle. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next card, forming a new inner circle with the children who like what’s on that card.

Talk About Playing With Friends Discuss who liked which activities. Suggest to children that they can ask friends who like the same things they like to play with them during independent center time and outside time. Help them practice asking, “Would you like to play with me?”

Some children may need help identifying what the picture shows before they can decide whether they like it or not. When you first show the cards, ask for volunteers to state aloud what the picture shows. Provide help as necessary.
Invite children to draw pictures of things they like to do with friends. They can write or dictate descriptions of the activities or label the names of the friends involved.

When talking about activities, take time to model language patterns. For example, ask, Do you like to run?, What do you like about running?, Do you like to draw?, What do you like about drawing? Helping children learn to recognize language patterns will support their exponential language growth.

You may wish to provide materials to support children’s sensory experience during this activity. For example, provide clay when talking about clay, blocks when talking about blocks, etc. This hands-on support will help the children’s engagement as well as their understanding of the activity.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We read the book A Friend Like You and saw that Squirrel and the bird could be good friends even though they were different from each other.
We learned about the word delicious. When something is delicious, it tastes really good.

In this activity, we’ll look at pictures of different foods and talk about whether we think they are delicious. Because we are different people, we might find that we think different foods are delicious.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs-up if they think the picture shows something delicious.

Ask Show a card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed. Allow for a few minutes of discussion before children give the thumbs-up or thumbs-down for this visual.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the card to a child to put into the “delicious” pile or the “not delicious” pile, depending on which category has the most votes.
Repeat Continue the activity with the next card.
Talk About Friendship Review any interesting discussions that came up during the activity. Explain that even good friends can like different foods.

If children need additional support with this activity, model answering each question yourself before inviting a child to answer. Be sure to mention that you have friends who like different foods than you like.

Invite children to write or draw about other foods they think are delicious. Encourage them to talk with each other to learn how other children feel about those foods. Ask if they learned about a new food during the activity.

Encourage multilingual learners to share the words they use to describe a delicious food. Also, invite children to talk about a favorite meal their family makes at home. You may wish to follow up by asking families to send you a photo of a favorite meal they eat at home so you can print the photos and make them available in the dramatic play center.

To add some fun fine motor movement to this activity, consider providing forks, spoons, chopsticks and pretend food for children to play with as part of the activity. Challenge them to use the utensils to move the pretend food from one plate to another.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Have blank drawing or other paper and art supplies ready to pass out to children to use as they create their “I am thankful for . . .” drawings.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we looked at the poster called Thank You, Friend! We learned about how we can show our good friends that we are thankful for them. It’s important to be thankful for all the people we love.
In this activity, we’ll think about people we are thankful for and draw pictures of them for an “I am thankful for . . .” display.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Provide Prompt Ask children to identify a person they are thankful for and tell why they are thankful for them.
Encourage Encourage children to draw a picture of the person with as much detail as possible.
Write Invite children to write or dictate the person’s name and why they are thankful for the person.
Share Gratitude Ask each child to share his or her drawing with the group. Then, work together to post the drawings on a bulletin board or wall for children and families to see.

If children are having a hard time coming up with something to draw for the different prompts, brainstorm ideas with them. Ask: Have any of your friends done something nice for you lately? What was it? How did it make you feel?

Encourage children to write a thank you note to the person they are thankful for. Put the note in an envelope with the person’s name on it and help the child find the best way to deliver it. If you do not know the person, give the note to the child’s family.

Encourage multilingual learners to talk about their drawings and tell you what they are thankful for. They may choose to use words from their home language in the captions that they dictate to you. If necessary, get help from other native speakers of that language.

Children might want to use additional art supplies to add details to their drawings. They can also cut pictures from old magazines to glue onto their drawings to represent the things for which they are thankful.
